ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

NEW SCHOOLS IN TELOK BLANGAH
(Particulars)


    1. Mr Rohan bin Kamis asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education how many new schools will be built in Telok Blangah and when they will be completed.

     The Senior Minister of State for Education (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam) (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering this question on behalf of my Minister.

    Sir, four primary schools and two secondary schools will be built in Telok Blangah. Three primary schools will be completed by December 1982 and two secondary schools by June 1982. The site for the fourth primary school has yet to be allocated by the Planning Department of the Ministry of National Development.

Column: 911

KAMPONG SAN TENG COMMUNITY CENTRE
(Yuan Xiao Cycling Exhibition)


    2. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Home Affairs why permission was not granted to the Kampong San Tong Community Centre Management Committee to hold the Yuan Xiao Cycling Exhibition and procession.

Column: 912



     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Kampong San Teng Community Centre Management Committee proposed to hold a static Bicycle Exhibition at the Ang Mo Kio community centre from 10.00 a.m. to 4.00 p.m. and a vehicular procession from 7 p.m. to 10 p.m. on 1st March this year. No permit was required from the Police to hold the static Bicycle Exhibition, and it was held at the void deck of Block 324, Ang Mo Kio Avenue 3, on 1st March, 1980.

    The Police did not give permission to hold the vehicular procession because it would have created traffic congestion and safety hazards. The procession was to consist of two lorries, one mini-bus, 60 bicycles and 30 trishaws. The route proposed was Ang Mo Kio Avenue 3/Ang Mo Kio Avenue 1/Upper Thomson Road/Sin Min Road and Upper Thomson Rood, ending at the Kampong San Tong community centre. The proposed route has eight traffic-light junctions and includes some busy main roads which are busiest between 6 p.m. and 8 p.m. The procession would have drawn large crowds of onlookers at road sides and dividers and traffic islands. This would have not only resulted in traffic congestion but created hazards to onlookers and motorists as well.

SINGAPORE SOCIETY OF ACCOUNTANTS
(Council representation)


    3. Mr Rohan bin Kamis asked the Minister for Finance (a) whether he is aware of the unhappiness among members of the

Column: 913

Singapore Society of Accountants about (i) the voting procedures for the election of members of the Council; and (ii) the disproportionate representation of public accountants vis-a-vis registered accountants on the Council; and (b) whether he will consider taking steps to remedy the situation.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Goh Chok Tong) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering this question on behalf of the Minister for Finance.

    The voting procedures for the election of members to the Council have been the subject of much discussion by members of the Society and the Council over the past few years. Resolutions were passed at the 1978 and 1979 Annual General Meetings of the Society calling for the abolition of the present system of voting by proxy. All these have culminated in a proposal submitted by the Council to the Ministry of Finance suggesting the replacement of proxy voting by a system of voting by postal ballot in addition to voting in person. The Minister for Finance has accepted this and the necessary amendments to the Rules will be gazetted shortly.

    On the point raised by the Member of disproportionate representation on the Council by public accountants as against registered accountants, the Act provides adequate safeguards through equal representation to ensure that neither category of members can dominate the Council.

     Mr Rohan bin Kamis (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, currently each group of accountants can vote in its own group only, i.e. public accountants vote in PAS candidates and registered accountants vote in RAS candidates. Would the Minister then consider removing the restriction on voting by group only, thereby allowing registered accountants to vote in both RAS candidates and PAS candidates, and public accountants to do likewise? This would ensure that the Council member has been voted in by the popular choice of the whole membership.

Column: 914

The group representation on the Council could, however, be left as it is.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Sir, if there is a recommendation to this effect by the Society, the Ministry of Finance will consider it.

CIVIL SERVICE
(Division I Officers)


    4. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Finance (a) how many Division I officers have been recruited since 1965; and (b) how many of the recruits were non-citizens and how many of them have been granted (i) permanent residence; and (ii) citizenship.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, again I am answering the question on behalf of the Minister for Finance.

    The recruitment of Division I officers is no longer the responsibility of the Ministry of Finance as this function has been taken over by the Establishment Unit of the Prime Minister's Office. Nonetheless, the Minister for Finance has collated the necessary information from the Public Service Commission and the Ministry of Home Affairs.

    The available records maintained by the Public Service Commission show that between 1965 and 1979, 6,082 Division I officers were recruited. However, statistics on the nationality of the recruits are only available from 1973. The figures (from 1973 to 1979) are as follows:- 
   Singapore citizens:       2,532       67%
   Permanent residents
         of Singapore:          68        1.8%
   Malaysian citizens:         886       23.5%
   Other citizens:             290        7.7%

                    Total:   3,776      100 %


    The available records at the Ministry of Home Affairs show that 302 Division I officers have acquired Singapore citizenship since 1965. The Ministry also introduced a scheme in 1967 whereby non-citizens

Column: 915

recruited to the Civil Service are granted permanent residence. Since then, 990 Division I officers have been granted permanent residence under the scheme.

DEVELOPMENT OF PRIVATE PROPERTY
(Particulars)


    5. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development (a) how many applications for the development of private property have been received since 1st January, 1976, and the number of (i) condominiums; (ii) terrace houses; (iii) semi-detached houses; and (iv) detached houses proposed for construction; (b) how many of these units have been sold; and (c) whether there are applications still awaiting approval for the various units specified and when approval will be given.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of applications received from the private sector for all types of development for the period 1.1.76 to 31.12.79 was 41,278. Of this figure, 1,633 applications were for residential development comprising:

    (i) 283 applications or 29,565 units for condominiums;

    (ii) 140 applications or 1,184 units for terrace houses;

    (iii) 231 applications or 1,134 units for semi-detached houses;

    (iv) 340 applications or 571 units for detached houses; and

    (v) 639 applications or 15,992 units for flats.

    Out of 1,633 residential applications, 871 applications totalling 16,754 units were approved.

    Approval of planning applications does not necessarily result in subsequent construction and sale of such units. Some developers for their own reasons may not proceed with development. Statistics collected under the Housing Developers Act show that 1,543 residential units approved over the period

Column: 916

1.1.76 to 30.9.79 were sold. These comprise 1,190 flats and condominiums, 188 terrace houses, 140 semi-detached houses and 25 detached houses.

    To-date, 43 applications for residential development are under processing and decisions are expected in one to two months' time.

Column: 916

BUKIT MERAH TOWN CENTRE
(Sports and recreational amenities)


    6. Mr Rohan bin Kamis asked the Minister for National Development (a) what amenities will be provided for Telok Blangah residents at the Bukit Merah Town Centre and when these will be completed; and (b) what other sports and recreational amenities are planned for Telok Blangah.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, the Bukit Merah Town Centre will serve Telok Blangah New Town and the Bukit Merah area. Its development is almost completed. The amenities presently available include shops, offices, hawker centres, restaurant and eating houses, a cinema, social function hall and polyclinic. The swimming complex, presently under construction, will be ready by January 1981. There are also plans to provide a branch library and another cinema.

    Construction of a basketball court for Telok Blangah New Town will commence in May 1980. The Housing and Development Board plans to build another two basketball courts and four hard courts for badminton, volley ball and sepak takraw.

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [5th march 1980],

    "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year lot April, 1980 to 31st March, 1981.". - [Mr Goh Chok Tong, Minister for Trade and Industry].

    Question again proposed.
2.45 p.m.

     Mr C.V. Devan Nair (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Budget session is always the season for scapegoats - a hunting spree which inspires enthusiasm on both Front and Back Benches, but perhaps a bit more on the Back Benches.

    We might start by asking what the origin and meaning of the "scapegoat" is. It derives from ancient Hebrew. Among the ancient Jews, a goat was sent into the wilderness on Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, bearing the iniquities of the people which are symbolically laid on its head by the High Priest.

    I have not been able to discover what happened to the goat thereafter. But we might reasonably suppose that at least some of the crowd, both priestly and profane, must have followed the poor goat, thus burdened with the sins of the community, into the wilderness, chopped its head off, feasted on the mutton, and felt purified until such time as they became sufficiently defiled by the next Atonement Day, when they would look for another goat to bear their sins and to feast upon.

    There is one particular scapegoat (or scapegoats) I am interested in; not in pursuing it into the wilderness and to feast upon the mutton. On the contrary, I am interested in taking a long overdue swipe at those groups in our society who have been saying unkind things about these scapegoats. For if they are sent into the wilderness, Singapore would perish. I refer, Sir, to our entrepreneurs, technocrats, professionals, skilled workers and political

Column: 919

leaders who have between them securely laid the material foundations of our social and economic well-being.

    Sir, the Minister was able to present the kind of budget he did because the Prime Minister and his Cabinet colleagues never allowed themselves to live in cloud-cuckoo land. Beginning May 1959, when the PAP first took the reins of power in Singapore, they grappled with economic realities, not with ideological or metaphysical abstractions.

    From the word "Go", their primary preoccupation was how to generate wealth, and how to garner and use wealth productively for social, educational, housing, health, cultural and developmental ends. In order to do this, they developed a realistic respect for wealth-generating factors, including the wealth generators themselves.

    And they never regarded profit as a dirty word, as something sordid and unspiritual. The healthier the profit position of an enterprise, whether private or public, the better for the workers, for the public exchequer, and therefore for Singapore as a whole. Profiteering is a dirty word, but not profits. And that is why the NTUC founded CASE and the Government helps to fund it.

    Also vitally important to economic progress was the fact that neither the political nor the trade union leaders subscribed to the imbecile egalitarian creed of unearned rewards and unrewarded duties. Societies which adopted this creed are today the broken-back societies of the Third World, but it would be invidious to name them. In Singapore, both the individual and the notion as a whole must earn their keep. Performance, merit, productivity, the international and national market value of the skills or expertise involved - and not the rules of the lucky draw - determine a person's earnings.

    Let our budding breed of new writers, poets and "back to the Beyond" philosophers also chew on the fact that foreign investors come to Singapore with their technology and their marketing skills, not because of the quality of our poets and philo-

Column: 920

sophers but because of the quality of our social and economic infrastructure, the skills of our workers, and the assurance of a healthy return on their investments.

    Let everybody also be assured that nobody in the political leadership regards affluence and economic well-being as ends in themselves but as the necessary material foundation for the development of higher intellectual, cultural and spiritual appetites in our people.

    Some distinguished modern spiritual leaders, in both East and West, have affirmed that the higher things of life cannot exist or develop on empty bellies, on poverty and squalor. If the PAP Government had started off with poetry and philosophy, none of our poets today would be able to poetise the way they do, none of our liberals to liberalise the way they do, and none of our philosophers to philosophise the way they do.

    One would have thought that all the simple basics I have listed are accepted as axiomatic in Singapore. They are not, and I will explain why.

    One of the less desirable by-products of our increasing affluence and better education are the snooty arty-crafty types, who denounce materialism and materialists. And when they refer to materialists, they are not merely thinking of our Foreign Minister's "Ugly Singaporean" whose religion is moneytheism, who sees wealth as an end in itself, who is completely self-centred with no social concern whatever, and whose tastes in music, art and literature are vulgar in the extreme.

    On the contrary, according to the snooty arty-crafty chaps, even the word "technocrat" is a term of abuse. And mere politicians like all of us in this House, from the Prime Minister downwards, belong to a lesser breed, people who think in mechanical terms, and are completely divorced from the rarefied worlds of art, music and literature in which these higher spiritual beings float about. They even turn down their lofty spiritual noses on something which we lesser breeds desperately seek for the

Column: 921

physical survival of Singapore - technology.

    Fortunately for Singapore, these bogus mystics of the spirit are in the minority. And they let off their verbal blasts against the materialistic and mechanical types like us, without taking the trouble to do their homework. Equally fortunately, because of the hard-nosed sophistication of our electorate, any one of these loafers of the spirit would lose his deposit if he stood for election. However, because of their glibness and their great capacity for verbal gymnastics, they do have a capacity to mislead those of our young people who take the arts and the humanities as their field of study.

    The scapegoat seekers I have in mind come from the now breed of writers in Singapore. Not all of them, mind you, but at least some of them, especially those whom I have called the arty-crafty types. I know at least one of them, a Singapore citizen, who goes into raptures when leader writers of the Manchester Guardian take one of their regular, vicious and ignorant swipes at Singapore and our Prime Minister, but maintains a morose and sullen silence when Singapore speaks out against its foreign detractors.

    Before I wade into these gentlemen (and ladies!) I might offer my own credentials. In doing so, I know that the position I will take will be shared by the generality of Members in this House.

    I am ignorant about Singapore writers who use Mandarin, Malay or Tamil as their means of expression. But I have gone through a good number of those who offer their literary creations in English. A surprising number of them write well, and deserve praise and encouragement. No society is complete without its literati. So may they increase in number and flourish! But what some among the literati do not seem to appreciate is that no literati will be possible, without the rest of society, including our much-maligned entrepreneurs, technocrats and other "materialistic" types who are responsible for the foundation of

Column: 922

material well-being in our society, and for the solid material launching pad from which our literati are able to shoot up into their ethereal spiritual orbits.

    A good number of our poets, for instance, have managed memorable lines, and some even memorable verses of a sustained high quality. But alas, an equal number of them have also produced execrable stuff which they attempt to palm off as poetry. These are the confidence tricksters of literature - apes of style, barren of substance, and devoid of sincerity. And they exist in all societies. Only, we seem to have more than our fair share of such posturing humbugs. We could do with less. I would not mention names, but those who squirm when they read this in the papers tomorrow, will know whom the cap fits.

    I might confess that I am temperamentally incapable of responding to some kinds of poetry, and the fault may be my own lack of receptivity. For instance, verses which offer me the erotic ecstasies which the poet has experienced, leave me unexcited. But this may be because with increasing age, some of my glands do not function as efficiently as they used to.

    Along with our writers, there have also emerged the literary critics. Here, there appear to be two schools, one a club of mutual masturbators, who are constantly praising each other's works, and the other of critics who use hatchets with great vigour to chop up matchsticks.

    In this connection, Mr Speaker, Sir, may I toll the Minister of Education that I was alarmed to learn that in our secondary schools, a number of our local poets are read during appreciation of poetry sessions. I am alarmed, Sir, because I know a number of them who ought not to be read at all. I would submit that until such time as we develop in Singapore nationally as well as internationally credible standards of literary criticism, it would be safer to introduce our children to English poetry through universally acknowledged models of poetic content and diction like Wordsworth, Shelley, Milton, Shakespeare, and so on. I mean this seriously, for if I find that my daughter who is

Column: 923

in secondary school now, develops depraved tastes in poetry, I may feel obliged to sue the Ministry of Education.

    I will now say something about the credentials of the generation which made the Singapore of today, which the next generation will inherit. We must give these credentials, so that the arty-crafty dodgers of reality are not allowed to denigrate the virtues and, if I may say so, the passion, which went into the making of modern Singapore.

    The Singapore we know today, warts and all, and are justifiably proud of, is not the product of our sins. It is the product and image of the virtues of a whole generation of people. What were some of the crucial collective experiences which went into the making of this generation?

    They were children or adolescents during the great Wall Street collapse of the early 30s, followed by the Great Depression.

    I remember that as an eight-year old boy, my unemployed father with my mother and seven of us children (There was no Lee Kuan Yew then to say "Only two", and a decent interval in between. There was hardly any interval between us.) were forced to live for nearly two years in a dilapidated garage near Muar. And we did not have meat or even fish for weeks on end. Others fared much worse, sleeping on five-foot ways and tin shacks.

    Then came the maelstrom of the Second World War, the unrelieved horrors, the massacres and tortures associated with the Japanese occupation. The end of World War 11 and the British re-occupation did not bring with it peace and tranquillity. On the contrary, members of that generation found themselves caught up in a swelling, impetuous and irresistible tide of anti-colonialism which was to irrevocably change the political face of Asia. There followed rapid political changes, accompanied by social turbulence, riots, strikes, arson, bomb explosions, and the like - which Singaporeans of today are strangers to. And many a time it was a touch-and-go affair in successive and often simultaneous confrontations

Column: 924

with the colonialists, the crooks, the communalists and the communists - the four C's if you prefer.

    It was no ordinary generation, both leaders and led, which between them forged this nation into being, for they went through a fiery baptism which we sincerely hope that our children will be spared. Many of them are with us no more, and with every passing year, the relentless attrition of time will remove more of them. And our vapid poets (not all of them, please!) with their anaemic, neurotic and erotic verses, cannot even in their most vivid imaginings, capture the drama, the pain, passion, courage and sometimes sheer heroism which formed the warp and woof of the lives of the founding generation of Singaporeans.

    And yet, the very uniqueness of Singapore is now used as a stick to hit us with. Here is a prize piece of nincompoopery. I quote from a forum on English language and literature in Singapore, published in the last issue of Commentary, a quarterly journal of the University of Singapore Society. The speaker is a senior lecturer in the University's Department of English. I quote:

    'Quite unabashedly and without apology, the Prime Minister has said, if I remember correctly, that in the 60s, the early 60s, when there was a baby boom, the Government lowered standards of admission for teachers and they just admitted anybody, [including daily-rated labourers!]. And he took it as an accepted fact that we had to do this. The result has been a decline in standards of English, mainly or partly because of the decline in the quality of teachers. But the PM's remark points to something: in Singapore the solution is always mechanical. Numbers all the time. We think that once we assemble a number of people, a number of resources, and so on, hey presto, something will happen.'

More about this person later on.

    So our Prime Minister is too mechanical. Remember the passion I referred to? But no, the Prime Minister is devoid of passion. He is a robot. His solutions are always mechanical. So we had better have an artist as our next Prime Minister. He would not be mechanical. Perhaps we might try out the chap who writes that poetry corner in the Sunday Times. He will not be mechanical, for he probably does not even know what machines are - let alone poetry!

Column: 925



    I remember the Prime Minister had given the rationale behind the decision to lower standards of admission for teachers in the early 60s. But there is no mention of this. However, the senior lecturer is absolutely right in at least one respect. We did assemble a number of incorruptible people, a number of resources, and organised a hard-working population, and hey presto, something did happen - the swamps of Jurong gave way to an industrial estate, the slums of Singapore gave way to our numerous townships - and hey presto, we have got the Singapore of today. Only, we did not bargain for this senior lecturer in the Department of English.

    I will continue with the quotation from this inspired senior lecturer:

    'The other point I want to make is about the style of the leadership. If you look at the speeches, they always bring in statistics. We must be about the only country where the Prime Minister releases a sat of tables with his text. Every National Day speech contains productivity figures and projections of trade figures, GNP, and so on. So one does not really need great expressive power'.

Our PM has no expressive power as you all know! And the same kind of mindless gibberish goes on and on. This is the kind of intellectual food served to our students in the arts and humanities departments.
